fields.label_text:
Vase or jar, glazed earthenware, with globular body and broad grooved handles, decorated in relief with armorial shields, tendrils, masks, coloured green and manganese.
Italian, 15th century
Bought (Castellani Collection)

Jar, earthenware
Bearing the monogram 'pv' surmounted by a cross
Italian (probably Florentine), first half of 15th century

21. Jar with decoration in relief 
Italy (Orvieto), 1395-1430
Decorated with the arms of the Ottoni family
Earthenware painted with colours into the opaque tin-glaze 
This jar would have been used for display or in a pharmacy.
Museum no.671-1884. Bought from the Castellani Collection.

fields.descriptive_line: Two-handled earthenware jug covered with a tin glaze (maiolica) and painted in green, brown and yellow over relief decorations of stylised leafs, flowers, masks and coats of arms. Italian, probably made in Orvieto, 1395-1430
fields.physical_description: Globular body and broad grooved handels, decorated in relief with armorial shields, tendrils and masks, coloured green amd manganese. A mark, consisting of a double cross aboe a letter or letters, occurs four times
fields.materials_techniques: Buff-coloured earthenware covered with tin glaze and painted in maganese brown and copper green

21. Jar with decoration in relief

fields.public_access_description:
This large jar was used to store dry goods, probably for use as medicines. The coat of arms would indicate that it was made for a particular family and so may have been intended for a pharmacy within the family's home. The style of decoration with applied masks in relief would date it to the latter part of the 14th century or into the early decades of the 15th century.

The arms have tentively been identified as those of the Ottoni family who were based in Matelica in the Marche region of Italy. The Ottoni family has arms with a checky base in the shield but they are tinctured gules (red) and argent (white). It was not possible at this time to achieve a red colour and so the potter may have substituted yellow for the red parts of the checky base.

Jars with very similar decoration have been attributed to ceramic production centres in Orvieto, in the Umbrian region of Italy. Documentary evidence informs us that Orivieto was a production centre from the 13th century. Ceramic manufacture here began to decline in the latter part of the 14th century as it was badly affected by the ravages of the Black Death. 

In the late 19th and early 20th cetnries, the Italian government was investing in the redevelopment of towns such as Orivieto. A large number of medieval ceramics were discovered in the old water systems of the town such as in wells. Accurate dating of these ceramics was not possible but more recent excavations enable us to date these ceramics more precisely.

Green and brown decoration seems to have been characteristic of Orivieto production from its beginnings in the middle of the 13th century and into the 15th century. This simple colour scheme is also found in Tuscany, Liguria, and other centres bordering on the western Mediterranean in France and in Spain. Availibility of colouring agents and the popularity of this colour scheme influenced its spread and longevity.
fields.bibliography:
Galeazzo Cora, La storia della maiolica di Firenze e del contado secoli XIV e XV, Florence, 2 vols., 1973
fig. 30c and p.41 Nelle illustrazioni ho mostrato un orciuolo biansato con decorazione rilievo assegnato dalla critica alla nostra zona. Altri ve ne sono; no ho pero sinora veduto frammenti de questo genere che siano stati sicuramente trovati qui.
La ceramica orvietana del medioevo, exhibition catalogue, Milano, 1983
fig.25 Badge of the Comune medievale di Orvieto - displayed eagle.
Bernard Rackham, Catalogue of Italian Maiolica in the Victoria & Albert Museum, London, 1940
Catalogue 33:
Jar with two elbowed handles each consisting of five separate bands, the middle one plaited; neck missing. On each side is a shield applied in relief surmounted by a woman's mask and flanked by symmetrically branching stems with flowers, buds and trefoil foliage, also in relief, picked out in green and enclosed in "contour" compartments reserved on a cross-hatched ground. The shields are charged: Checky argent and gules, on a chief or a demy eagle displayed issuant sable (gules is rendered by scratching away the enamel after glazing so as to expose the buff body, or by similarly exposing the body before the application of the transparent glaze (coperta), and sable by painting in manganese purple). On either side of both shields and under each handle is the same monogram, composed apparently of the script minuscules p and v surmounted by a double traverse cross with four dots. 
First half of 15th century
Castellani Collection

Wallis, Figure design, fig.54
Bode, Anfange, pl.XIII
Guide, p.29
Probably made in or near Florence (perhaps at Montelupo). Compare no.25. The arms are probably those of the Ottoni, imperial but afterwards (1394) papal vicars of Matelica in the Fabriano-Camerino district of the Marches (Checky argent and gules, with a chief of the Empire). A checky fo the same tinctures (but of nine pieces 3 and 3) was borne by the Lombard line of the house of Pallavicino. It has been suggested that the monogram is for Praefectus  Urbi (i.e. prefect of Rome) but no holder of this office bears the arms in question.
Ceramiche Orvietane dei secoli XIII et XIV
Tav.X-XIII for examples of Orvieto relief work from the Alessandro Imbert collection.
Julia E. Poole, Italian Maiolica and Incised Slipware in the Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge, Cambridge UP, 1995
cat.145 For similar relief-work jar.
La donazione Galeazzo Cora. Ceramiche dal medioevo al XIX secolo, Museo Internazionale delle ceramiche in Faenza, n.d.
fig. (B&W and colour) 200 There is a jug with the same arms, bit rendered only in green and brown, in the Faenza Museum - formerly in the collection of Galeazzo Cora. He attibuted it to possibly Viterbo, 14th century.
fields.history_note: This jar was bought from the Castellani Collection of maiolica in 1884.
